channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Live: Covid-19 updates from New Zealand and around the world for 22 May
item.description: Auckland Council's revenue could fall by $550 million because of the Covid-19 crisis, and is preparing to spend $65m on a hardship package for ratepayers.

item.title: Friend describes man shot by police in Waitara as a 'tough and cool guy'
item.description: A lifelong friend of the man shot and killed by police in Waitara this week says he doesn't hold a grudge against the officers involved in the death of Alan Rowe - who he simply knew as Snow.

item.title: Reflections: Young people on life in lockdown
item.description: Lockdown was a time some of us might remember fondly; days spent with family, going for walks, pressing the reset button. For others, it was something best forgotten.

item.title: Covid-19: Road toll jumps back up after lockdown
item.description: The rate of people dying on our roads has jumped back up, following a record low during lockdown.

item.title: Board chair says DHB was forced to choose cheaper building option
item.description: Canterbury DHB has revealed it asked for $438m to rebuild its strained hospital but has had no choice but to settle for a third of that.

item.title: Calls for Mururoa veterans and descendants registry
item.description: There are calls for a registry to be established for Mururoa veterans and their families after research revealed prevalent health woes linked to radiation exposure.

item.title: Targeted response could be needed for rural communities - NZIER
item.description: Rural communities which are already deprived or reliant on tourism will need the most support to recover from the pandemic's economic damage.

item.title: Auckland Council Covid-19 losses could reach $550m
item.description: Auckland Council's revenue could fall by $550 million because of the Covid-19 crisis, and is preparing to spend $65m on a hardship package for ratepayers.

item.title: Demand for food parcels levels off, but could return, Sallies says
item.description: A second wave of Covid-19 hardship could be on the way, the Salvation Army has warned.

item.title: Employers divided on concept of four-day working week
item.description: The Prime Minister's comments encouraging employers to explore a four-day working week are being met with a flurry of mixed reactions from the business and tourism sectors.

item.title: WINZ begins to back pay people wrongly denied benefits
item.description: People who were wrongly denied the benefit based on redundancy payments say they are "delighted" Work and Income has reviewed their cases and agreed to back pay them.

item.title: Sex workers struggle with contact tracing clients
item.description: Sex workers say they are struggling to balance the privacy of their clients with the need to record contact tracing information.

item.title: Covid-19: what happened in NZ and worldwide on 21 May
item.description: New figures show a dramatic drop in homicide, robbery and sexual violence charges during lockdown; bars are re-opening; nurses reject their pay offer and Covid-19 cases top 5 million.

item.title: Covid-19 separation: NZ nurse suffers 'hardest two weeks of my life'
item.description: Tears flowed during a reunion between two sisters in a small New South Wales town marking the end of a nearly two-month battle to grant a dying wish.

item.title: Epidemic Response Committee meets with religious leaders ahead of gatherings decision
item.description: The Epidemic Response Committee has today talked to religious leaders ahead of Monday's decision on increasing the size of gatherings.

item.title: Manaaki Whenua Māori land tool aids kiwi conservation
item.description: A mapping resource has been launched to help iwi and conservation groups track their progress in restoring rivers, tāonga species and endangered animals.

item.title: Drought-hit Hawke's Bay farmers get $500,000 from Budget
item.description: Drought-stricken Hawke's Bay farmers will be given $500,000 by the government, to help them through one of the worst dry spells in living memory.

item.title: Covid-19 could revive single-use plastics - agribusiness head
item.description: The Covid-19 crisis could be a big setback to progress on eliminating plastics, a rural expert has warned.
